", "choices": [{"text": "decryption", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Decryption is actually the process of converting cipher text back into plain text. For example: khoor ----> hello"}, {"text": "frequency analysis", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That's right! Frequency analysis is the technique whereby you count the letters in the secret message. In English, the letter with the highest frequency is 'e'. By counting letter frequencies you can identify the shift that was used to encrypt the message. That is why the Caesar cipher is not a secure cipher."}, {"text": "encryption", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Encryption is actually the process of converting plain text into cipher text. "}], "version": "1.5", "type": 0}

", "choices": [{"text": "Logarithmic", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Logarithmic algorithms usually involve a "divide and conquer" step. {"defaultFeedback": "URL for the Data Project page of your portfolio:
Example: http://www.mysite.com/dataprojectwriteup.html", "rows": 2, "description": "DP - Directions", "hint": "", "graders": [{"matcher": "regex", "score": "33", "response": "/.*/i", "feedback": "Thank you for submitting!"}], "question": "

The Assignment

Work with a partner to identify and analyze a large data set that interests you. Your final project should be in the form of a PowerPoint presentation and a portfolio write up on the investigative process. You and your partner will also complete individual write-ups to submit. As you complete your project, keep track of your process on your portfolio.

Requirements

  1. Work collaboratively to research, investigate and analyze a Big Data set making sure that your project meets the following specifications.
    1. Data Sources: For this project, your large data set must contain at least 1000 data values/cells. (You may use one of these examples, but you are encouraged to find others!)
    2. Questions: For this assignment, create 3-5 questions that you believe can be answered using your chosen data set.
    3. Illustrations: For this assignment, create visualizations where appropriate that illustrate the answers to your questions (e.g. charts, graphs, etc.).
  2. Download the data and put it into a Google Fusion table.
  3. Work collaboratively to use the manipulation tools available on the Google Fusion table platform to answer your 3-5 questions.
  4. Create visualizations that illustrate the answers to your questions.
  5. Produce a collaborative write-up that will allow someone else to understand your investigation (your project) and its process.
  6. Give a 5-10 minute oral presentation with visuals (a PowerPoint with charts, graphs, etc.).
  7. When your project is complete, produce an individual write up that explains your project and the collaborative process used to complete the project.

Grading

Your project will be graded based on your portfolio write up. A helpful checklist with explanations for what to include in your write up is included in the How To: Create a Report Write Up document. Your write up will be graded using this Data Report Rubric.

Research
Criterion		 How to Score a 3 for Each Criterion
Questions?
 The report answers 3-5 research questions in a well-described and appropriate manner.
Data Sources?
 The selected data source(s) is/are relevant to the questions and contains at least 1000 cells.
Analysis
Criterion		 How to Score a 3 for Each Criterion
Approach?
 The report is logically and clearly describes the steps used to analyze the data.
Use of Data/Evidence?
 The report uses data to answer the questions well and effectively.
Data Relationships?
 The report identifies and describes data relationships that relate to the research questions.
Illustrations?
 The report contains illustrations (e.g. graphs, charts, videos, etc.) that clearly clarify analysis and findings.
Description of Analysis?
 The description of the analysis is well documented and contains little or no errors.
Writing Criterion How to Score a 3 for Each Criterion
Organization? The report is well organized in a way that is easy to follow.
Clarity? The report is clearly written and easy to follow/read for content.
Grammar and Spelling? The report contains few or no grammatical and spelling errors.

Submitting

Submit the URL of your project report write up on your portfolio. Make sure you read How To: Create a Report Write Up document to ensure you include all components.

(Example: http://www.mysite.com/dataprojectwriteup.html)

", "version": "1.5", "type": 1, "columns": 120}

rows.data: {"description": "5 Sort 4 Sorting Problems", "multiple_selections": true, "question": "For which of the problems would the bubble sort algorithm provide an appropriate solution. Choose all that apply. ", "choices": [{"text": "Arranging a deck of cards from the lowest to the highest value cards. ", "score": 0.33000000000000002, "feedback": "True. Bubble sort would be appropriate for sorting cards by their face value"}, {"text": "Looking up a name in the phone book.", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "No, a bubble sort would not be appropriate for looking up a name in the phone book. That's a search problem."}, {"text": "Sorting a stack of paper money into denominations -- i.e., $1, $5, $10 etc. ", "score": 0.33000000000000002, "feedback": "True. Bubble sort would be appropriate for sorting paper money by their denominations since we know that $1 come before $5 and $5 come before $10, etc."}, {"text": "Sorting a basket of laundry into socks, shirts, shorts, and sheets. ", "score": -1.0, "feedback": "No, a bubble sort would not be appropriate for sorting the laundry, unless you imposed some rule that socks come before shirts which come before sheets, and so on."}, {"text": "Arranging books on a bookshelf by author's last name. ", "score": 0.34000000000000002, "feedback": "True. Bubble sort would be appropriate for arranging books by author's last name since arranging by last name means sorting them in alphabetical order by last name."}], "version": "1.5", "type": 0}

", "choices": [{"text": "Sequential search", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "No, a sequential search behaves like the linear function."}, {"text": "Binary search", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That's right! rows.data:
{"defaultFeedback": "URL for the Create Performance Task page of your portfolio:
Example: http://www.mysite.com/project1writeup.html", "rows": 2, "description": "CP1 - Directions", "hint": "", "graders": [{"matcher": "regex", "score": "36", "response": "/.*/i", "feedback": "Thank you for submitting! You should now be able to access the peer reviews. (Go back to the main course page and a link to peer reviews will appear below this assessment.)"}], "question": "

The Assignment

Work with a partner to create a socially useful interactive app, that uses graphics and drawing, as well as other new concepts that you may have discovered. You may also use the Resources page, as needed. (You may find the One Minute Lessons helpful).  As you develop your project keep track of significant errors and bugs that you encountered and how you solved or debugged them.

Requirements

  1. With your partner, brainstorm a project idea, develop drawing(s) of the User Interface and a rough storyboard of how your app will function. You can use this template. Your app should be as complex as Paint Pot 2.
  2. Meet with your instructor to discuss the feasibility of the app and if necessary make any changes in your plan.
  3. Present a short (2-3 minute) elevator pitch of your project idea to the class. The pitch could follow this template:
    [name of app] is a [kind of thing it is] for [the people who would use it] that, unlike [similar apps] is able to [the major distinguishing feature of your app].
  4. Work collaboratively to develop, test, and debug your app, making sure that it meets the following criteria.
    1. Documentation of Code: For this assignment, a well documented app means having well named components, variables, and procedures. No additional comments are required.
    2. Data: For this assignment, your app should make appropriate use of variables.
    3. Algorithms: For this assignment, your app should make appropriate use of sequence and selection control structures.
    4. Abstraction: For this assignment, your app should include an abstraction of a real world concept or object.
    5. Feature Specifications: For this assignment your app should make appropriate use of graphics and drawing.
  5. Create a portfolio write up of your project.
  6. Give a 5-10 minute oral presentation by walking the class through your portfolio write up and providing a live demo of your working app.

Grading

Your project will be graded based on your portfolio write up. A helpful checklist with explanations for what to include in your write up is included in the How To: Create a Portfolio Write Up document. Your write up will be graded using this App Assessment Rubric.

App Design Criterion How to Score a 3 for Each Criterion
Does It Work? The app works exactly as intended, without crashing, and contains no detectable errors or bugs.
Ease of Use? The app is easy to use, by a novice user, in an obvious way and/or there are instructions on how to use it properly.
User Interface? The app’s user interface is attractive and provides an effective way to use the app for its intended purpose.
Documentation of Code? The source code (the blocks and components) is descriptively named and easy to read (i.e. self-documenting). The source code contains informative comments where required.
Data? The app makes appropriate and effective use of data for the problem it solves. The app meets the specific data requirements that are included in this assignment.
Abstraction? The app makes appropriate and effective use of procedural abstraction and/or data abstraction for the problem it solves. The app meets the specific abstraction requirements that are included in this assignment.
Algorithms? The app makes appropriate and effective use of algorithms for the problem it solves. The app meets the specific algorithm requirements that are included in this assignment.
Specifications? The app meets all specifications listed for this assignment.
Write Up Criterion How to Score a 3 for Each Criterion
Organization? The write up is well organized in a way that is easy to follow.
Clarity? The write up is clearly written and easy to follow/read for content.
Grammar and Spelling? The write up contains few or no grammatical and spelling errors.

Submitting

Submit the URL of your performance task write up on your portfolio. Make sure you read How To: Create a Portfolio Write Up document to ensure you include all components.

(Example: http://www.mysite.com/programmingperformancetask1writeup.html)

", "version": "1.5", "type": 1, "columns": 140}

rows.data: {"description": "5 Analysis Tractable or not", "multiple_selections": false, "question": "Tractable or intractable? For any length string of letters 'a' through 'z', write down all possible words.", "choices": [{"text": "Tractable", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "There are 26 possible 1-letter words, 26 × 26 2 letter words, 26 × 26 × 26 3-letter words, and so on. So there would be 26N N-letter words. This is exponential. "}, {"text": "Intractable", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "Yes. If the string has N letters 'a' to 'z', then there are 26N possible strings, which is exponential. This is similar to finding all possible cryptographic keys where keys consists of N bits. In that case it would be just 2N because each bit can be only 1 or 0. In this case, each letter can be one of 26 possible letters. "}], "version": "1.5", "type": 0}

rows.data: {"description": "5 Debug 7 Debugging a Program", "multiple_selections": false, "question": "Your classmate discovers that their MoleMash app has a bug in it. What should he/she do to debug their app? ", "choices": [{"text": "Rebuild the app and then retest the app ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "No, the programmer should not rebuild their entire app just because there is a bug in it. They should take their time to examine the code and form a hypothesis about what the bug may be. Then they should design and implement an experiment, and then debug and retest their app."}, {"text": "Form a hypothesis about what might be wrong, design an experiment to test their hypothesis, perform the experiment, debug, and then retest the app. \n", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "That's right! When debugging a program, a programmer should form a hypothesis about what the bug might be, then design and implement an experiment to test their hypothesis. If their hypothesis was correct, then the programmer should debug the app and retest. If their hypothesis was wrong, the programmer should form a new hypothesis"}, {"text": "Form a hypothesis and then retest the app. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "No, not quite. He/she should form a hypothesis about what could possible be wrong with the code, however, just forming a hypothesis and then retesting the app is not enough."}, {"text": "Immediately start changing code and retest the app. ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "No, it is not recommended that he/she start changing code without first thinking about, and forming an hypothesis, about what could possible be wrong. The programmer should take their time, form a hypothesis, design and implement an experiment, and then debug and retest theirapp."}], "version": "1.5", "type": 0}

", "choices": [{"text": "creates IP addresses for clients and servers ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "The DNS is a lookup service. When we type www.google.com into the address bar, the DNS translates www.google.com into Google's IP address (64.233.160.0) for us. If there is a syntax error, the compiler will inform you that there is an error."}, {"text": "programming language ", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "No, the programming language is the language the statements are written in. rows.data:
{"description": "5 Analysis Is a Prime", "multiple_selections": false, "question": "How would you classify this algorithm? 
Is N a prime
   For each number K from 2 to N/2
      if N is divisible by K 
         Output False
   Output True
", "choices": [{"text": "Logarithmic", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Logarithmic algorithms usually involve a "divide and conquer" step. This one does not."}, {"text": "Linear", "score": 1.0, "feedback": "Yes. In the worst case, when N is prime, the loop goes through N/2 calculations, each one testing whether N is divisible by K (i.e., whether N/K leaves a remainder of 0). So this is linear. Remember in analysis, we "abstract away" factors like 1/2 in the N/2 expression."}, {"text": "N Log N", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "Usually N Log N algorithms combine a linear loop with a "divide and conquer" loop. This one does not."}, {"text": "Quadratic", "score": 0.0, "feedback": "This algorithm is much more efficient than quadratic, which usually combines two nested linear loops."}], "version": "1.5", "type": 0}

Example: http://www.mysite.com/project1writeup.html", "rows": 2, "description": "EPT2 - Directions", "hint": "", "graders": [{"matcher": "regex", "score": "36", "response": "/.*/i", "feedback": "Thank you for submitting! You should now be able to access the peer reviews. (Go back to the main course page and a link to peer reviews will appear below this assessment.)"}], "question": "

The Assignment

Computing innovations have had considerable impact on the social, economic and cultural areas of our lives. To focus your work on this task, select a computing innovation that has significant impact, or the potential for significant impact on our society, economy, or culture, and that possesses the potential for both beneficial and harmful effects.

A. General Requirements

For this performance task, you are required to:
  • work alone while completing the task.
  • choose an innovation that has a significant effect on some population. The effect could be a small effect on more than a hundred people, or a very large effect on a smaller number of people.

B. Written Requirements

You will write responses to specific prompts associated with content requirements. Your responses should convey a deep level of understanding about your innovation and its impacts. Your responses must also include information learned from your references.

Innovation

Written responses must include:

  • the innovation name and a description of the intended purpose of the innovation. (100 words max)
  • an explanation of the technical details of this innovation in terms that someone completely unfamiliar with the innovation would understand. (100 words max)
  • a description of the role computing plays in implementing the functionality associated with the innovation. (100 words max)
  • a description of the relationship between data and the innovation. For example, you could describe the data used or produced by the innovation or any privacy issues associated with the innovation data. (100 words max)

Impacted Population

Written responses must include:

  • a description of the population that is impacted by the innovation, including population characteristics such as approximate size, socioeconomic status, geographic location, health, age, gender, ethnicity, race, sexual orientation, and disability. (100 words max)

Social, Economic, or Cultural Impact

Written responses must include:

  • a description of the long-term and short-term impacts (100 words max)
  • a description of the beneficial and harmful effects of the innovation (100 words max)

C. Visual Artifact

Choose one of the potential beneficial or harmful effects of the innovation you described in your previous response and use a computer to create a visual artifact related to it.

  • The visual artifact must be a visualization, graphic, or movie that provides additional insight to explain, clarify, or depict the beneficial or harmful effect of the innovation you selected.
  • Provide a written summary to describe how the visual artifact you created illustrates the benefit or harm of the innovation. (50 words max)

D. References

Include at least two – and no more than five – references/citations to sources used to formulate your responses to this performance task.

  • Each source must be a reliable newspaper/magazine article, book, news, or online source that anyone can access.
  • For each reference, provide the full citation identifying the author, title, and source. For online references, include the permanent URL and the date on which you accessed the reference.
  • At least two of the sources must have been created within the last two years.

Grading Rubric

Your project will be graded based on the documents you submit on your portfolio. Your project will be graded using this Explore Project Rubric.

Submitting

Upload your PDF write-up and visual artifact to your portfolio. Submit the URL of your performance task on your portfolio. (Example: http://www.mysite.com/exploreperformancetaskwriteup.pdf)

The Assignment

Computing innovations have had considerable impact on the social, economic and cultural areas of our lives. One example is sexting and phone monitoring software which has had significant impact on our society and has had both beneficial and harmful effects. For this task, read this article, then install and examine one of the phone monitoring apps listed below. Produce a written document that explains the ethics of phone monitoring software (including the app you selected). Your written document should discuss the impact that phone monitoring software has on our society and convey a deep level of additional understanding of mobile app technologies. You should also produce and submit an original visual artifact that illustrates the effect of phone monitoring software.

Phone monitoring apps (pick one of the following):

  • Teen Safe
  • Mobile Watchdog
  • Mobile Spy
  • Net Nanny

A. General Requirements

For this performance task, you are required to:
  • work alone while completing the task.
  • ensure that you do not plagiarize.

B. Written Requirements

You will write responses to specific prompts associated with content requirements. Your responses should convey a deep level of understanding about phone monitoring software and its impacts. Your responses must also include information learned from your references. 2-3 pages (700 words max).

Innovation

Written responses must include:

  • a description of phone monitoring software including the example you selected and the intended purpose of phone monitoring software. (100 words max)
  • an explanation of the technical details of phone monitoring software in terms that someone completely unfamiliar with phone monitoring software would understand. (100 words max)
  • a description of the role computing plays in implementing the functionality associated with the phone monitoring software. (100 words max)
  • a description of the relationship between data and phone monitoring software. For example, you could describe the data used or produced by phone monitoring software or any privacy issues associated with phone monitoring data. (100 words max)

Impacted Population

Written responses must include:

  • a description of the population that is impacted by phone monitoring software, including population characteristics such as approximate size, socioeconomic status, geographic location, health, age, gender, ethnicity, race, sexual orientation, and disability. (100 words max)

Social, Economic, or Cultural Impact

Written responses must include:

  • a description of the long-term and short-term impacts (100 words max)
  • a description of the beneficial and harmful effects of phone monitoring software (100 words max)

C. Visual Artifact

Choose one of the potential beneficial or harmful effects of phone monitoring software you described in your previous response and use a computer to create a visual artifact related to it.

  • The visual artifact must be a visualization, graphic, or movie that provides additional insight to explain, clarify, or depict the beneficial or harmful effect of phone monitoring software.
  • Provide a written summary to describe how the visual artifact you created illustrates the benefit or harm of phone monitoring software. (50 words max)
  • If your visual artifact is a video, its length cannot exceed one minute.

D. References

Include the references/citations for the two sources used to formulate your responses to this project.

  • For each reference, provide the full citation identifying the author, title, and source. For online references, include the permanent URL and the date on which you accessed the reference.

Grading Rubric

Your project will be graded based on the documents you submit on your portfolio. Your project will be graded using this Explore Project Rubric.

Submitting

Upload your PDF write-up and visual artifact to your portfolio. Submit the URL of your performance task on your portfolio. (Example: http://www.mysite.com/exploreperformancetaskwriteup.pdf)
